title: Example Usage
text: open-meteo project combines best models location across globe provide best possible forecast. open-meteo defines model = "generic". [https://open-meteo.com/en/docs]
code: df <- get_forecast(latitude = 37.30,                    longitude = -79.83,                    forecast_days = 7,                     past_days = 2,                     model = "generic",                    variables = c("temperature_2m")) head(df) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   datetime            reference_datetime  site_id   model_id variable prediction #>   <dttm>              <dttm>              <chr>     <chr>    <chr>         <dbl> #> 1 2024-08-25 00:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79… generic  tempera…       20.6 #> 2 2024-08-25 01:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79… generic  tempera…       20   #> 3 2024-08-25 02:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79… generic  tempera…       19.3 #> 4 2024-08-25 03:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79… generic  tempera…       18.7 #> 5 2024-08-25 04:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79… generic  tempera…       17.4 #> 6 2024-08-25 05:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79… generic  tempera…       18   #> # ℹ 1 more variable: unit <chr> df |>    mutate(variable = paste(variable, unit)) |>    ggplot(aes(x = datetime, y = prediction)) +    geom_line(color = "#F8766D") +    geom_vline(aes(xintercept = reference_datetime)) +    facet_wrap(~variable, scale = "free")

title: Example Usage
text: Ensemble forecasts individual models available. [https://open-meteo.com/en/docs/ensemble-api] Options models variables https://open-meteo.com/en/docs/ensemble-api Note ecmwf_ifs04 include solar radiation. List global model ids:
code: df <- get_ensemble_forecast(   latitude = 37.30,   longitude = -79.83,   forecast_days = 7,   past_days = 2,   model = "gfs_seamless",   variables = c("temperature_2m")) head(df) df |>    mutate(variable = paste(variable, unit)) |>    ggplot(aes(x = datetime, y = prediction, color = ensemble)) +    geom_line() +    geom_vline(aes(xintercept = reference_datetime)) +    facet_wrap(~variable, scale = "free", ncol = 2) icon_seamless, icon_global, gfs_seamless, gfs025, gfs05, ecmwf_ifs04, gem_global

what: Use with the General Lake Model
title: Example Usage
text: included functions allow output used General Lake Model ([https://doi.org/10.5194/gmd-12-473-2019]). Since open-meteo models include longwave radiation, package provides function calculate cloud cover air temperature. GLM requires set variables provided  following converts GLM format
code: df <- get_ensemble_forecast(   latitude = 37.30,   longitude = -79.83,   forecast_days = 7,   past_days = 2,   model = "gfs_seamless",   variables = glm_variables(product = "ensemble_forecast",                                          time_step = "hourly")) head(df) #> # A tibble: 6 × 8 #>   datetime            reference_datetime  site_id     model_id ensemble variable #>   <dttm>              <dttm>              <chr>       <chr>    <chr>    <chr>    #> 1 2024-08-25 00:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 gfs_sea… 00       relativ… #> 2 2024-08-25 00:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 gfs_sea… 01       relativ… #> 3 2024-08-25 00:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 gfs_sea… 02       relativ… #> 4 2024-08-25 00:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 gfs_sea… 03       relativ… #> 5 2024-08-25 00:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 gfs_sea… 04       relativ… #> 6 2024-08-25 00:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 gfs_sea… 05       relativ… #> # ℹ 2 more variables: prediction <dbl>, unit <chr> df |>    mutate(variable = paste(variable, unit)) |>    ggplot(aes(x = datetime, y = prediction, color = ensemble)) +    geom_line() +    geom_vline(aes(xintercept = reference_datetime)) +    facet_wrap(~variable, scale = "free", ncol = 2) path <- tempdir() df |>    add_longwave() |>   write_glm_format(path = path) head(read_csv(list.files(path = path, full.names = TRUE, pattern = ".csv")[1])) #> Rows: 216 Columns: 7 #> ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Delimiter: "," #> dbl  (6): AirTemp, ShortWave, LongWave, RelHum, WindSpeed, Rain #> dttm (1): time #>  #> ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. #> ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message. #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   time                AirTemp ShortWave LongWave RelHum WindSpeed  Rain #>   <dttm>                <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl>  <dbl>     <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 2024-08-25 00:00:00    19.5         0     314.     63      1.3      0 #> 2 2024-08-25 01:00:00    17.8         0     306.     70      1.14     0 #> 3 2024-08-25 02:00:00    16.6         0     301.     75      0.95     0 #> 4 2024-08-25 03:00:00    15.8         0     306.     79      0.72     0 #> 5 2024-08-25 04:00:00    15.1         0     311.     83      0.64     0 #> 6 2024-08-25 05:00:00    14.6         0     318.     86      0.67     0

what: Converting to Ecological Forecasting Initative convention
title: Example Usage
text: standard used NEON Ecological Forecasting Challenge slightly different standard package. uses column parameter ensemble Challenge standard allows flexibility use parametric distributions (.e., normal distribution mean sd) standard ensemble (sample) forecast. family column defines distribution (family = ensemble). EFI standard also follows CF-conventions variable names converted CF compliant. output convert_to_efi_standard() output neon4cast::stage2() Learn neon4cast::stage2() : [https://projects.ecoforecast.org/neon4cast-docs/Shared-Forecast-Drivers.html] Note neon4cast::stage3() similar difference number days equal past_days call get_ensemble_forecast(). max past_days open-meteo ~60 days.

title: Example Usage
text: need historical days model calibration testing, historical data available open-meteo’s historical weather API. [https://open-meteo.com/en/docs/historical-weather-api] Notice delay ~7 days.
code: df <- get_historical_weather(   latitude = 37.30,   longitude = -79.83,   start_date = "2023-01-01",   end_date = Sys.Date(),   variables = c("temperature_2m"))  tail(df |> na.omit()) #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   datetime            site_id     model_id variable       prediction unit  #>   <dttm>              <chr>       <chr>    <chr>               <dbl> <chr> #> 1 2024-08-25 19:00:00 37.3_-79.83 ERA5     temperature_2m       29.1 °C    #> 2 2024-08-25 20:00:00 37.3_-79.83 ERA5     temperature_2m       29.2 °C    #> 3 2024-08-25 21:00:00 37.3_-79.83 ERA5     temperature_2m       28.9 °C    #> 4 2024-08-25 22:00:00 37.3_-79.83 ERA5     temperature_2m       28.3 °C    #> 5 2024-08-25 23:00:00 37.3_-79.83 ERA5     temperature_2m       25.9 °C    #> 6 2024-08-26 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 ERA5     temperature_2m       23   °C df |>    mutate(variable = paste(variable, unit)) |>    ggplot(aes(x = datetime, y = prediction)) +    geom_line(color = "#F8766D") +    geom_vline(aes(xintercept = lubridate::with_tz(Sys.time(), tzone = "UTC"))) +    facet_wrap(~variable, scale = "free") #> Warning: Removed 47 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`).

title: Example Usage
text: Weather forecasts 9 months future available NOAA Climate Forecasting System [https://open-meteo.com/en/docs/seasonal-forecast-api]
code: df <- get_seasonal_forecast(   latitude = 37.30,   longitude = -79.83,   forecast_days = 274,   past_days = 5,   variables = c("temperature_2m")) head(df) #> # A tibble: 6 × 8 #>   datetime            reference_datetime  site_id     model_id ensemble variable #>   <dttm>              <dttm>              <chr>       <chr>    <chr>    <chr>    #> 1 2024-08-22 00:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 cfs      01       tempera… #> 2 2024-08-22 00:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 cfs      02       tempera… #> 3 2024-08-22 00:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 cfs      03       tempera… #> 4 2024-08-22 00:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 cfs      04       tempera… #> 5 2024-08-22 06:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 cfs      01       tempera… #> 6 2024-08-22 06:00:00 2024-08-27 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 cfs      02       tempera… #> # ℹ 2 more variables: prediction <dbl>, unit <chr> df |>    mutate(variable = paste(variable, unit)) |>    ggplot(aes(x = datetime, y = prediction, color = ensemble)) +    geom_line() +    geom_vline(aes(xintercept = reference_datetime)) +   facet_wrap(~variable, scale = "free") #> Warning: Removed 2133 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`).

what: Downscaling from 6 hour to 1 hour time-step
title: Example Usage
text: downscaling uses GLM variables
code: df <- get_seasonal_forecast(   latitude = 37.30,   longitude = -79.83,   forecast_days = 30,   past_days = 5,   variables = glm_variables(product = "seasonal_forecast",                              time_step = "6hourly")) #> Waiting 5s for throttling delay ■■■■■■                           #> Waiting 5s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■           #> Waiting 5s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■ df |>    six_hourly_to_hourly(latitude = 37.30, longitude = -79.83, use_solar_geom = TRUE) |>    mutate(variable = paste(variable, unit)) |>    ggplot(aes(x = datetime, y = prediction, color = ensemble)) +    geom_line() +    geom_vline(aes(xintercept = reference_datetime)) +    facet_wrap(~variable, scale = "free", ncol = 2) #> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'quantmod': #>   method            from #>   as.zoo.data.frame zoo

title: Example Usage
text: Climate projections different models available 2050. output daily time-step. Note units shortwave radiation different climate projection. [https://open-meteo.com/en/docs/climate-api]
code: df <- get_climate_projections(   latitude = 37.30,   longitude = -79.83,   start_date = Sys.Date(),   end_date = Sys.Date() + lubridate::years(1),   model = "EC_Earth3P_HR",   variables = c("temperature_2m_mean")) head(df) #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   datetime   site_id     model_id      variable            prediction unit  #>   <date>     <chr>       <chr>         <chr>                    <dbl> <chr> #> 1 2024-08-27 37.3_-79.83 EC_Earth3P_HR temperature_2m_mean       20.3 °C    #> 2 2024-08-28 37.3_-79.83 EC_Earth3P_HR temperature_2m_mean       20.7 °C    #> 3 2024-08-29 37.3_-79.83 EC_Earth3P_HR temperature_2m_mean       21.1 °C    #> 4 2024-08-30 37.3_-79.83 EC_Earth3P_HR temperature_2m_mean       21.9 °C    #> 5 2024-08-31 37.3_-79.83 EC_Earth3P_HR temperature_2m_mean       22.6 °C    #> 6 2024-09-01 37.3_-79.83 EC_Earth3P_HR temperature_2m_mean       21.9 °C df |>    mutate(variable = paste(variable, unit)) |>    ggplot(aes(x = datetime, y = prediction)) +    geom_line(color = "#F8766D") +    facet_wrap(~variable, scale = "free")

title: Example Usage
code: models <- c("CMCC_CM2_VHR4","FGOALS_f3_H","HiRAM_SIT_HR","MRI_AGCM3_2_S","EC_Earth3P_HR","MPI_ESM1_2_XR","NICAM16_8S")  df <- map_df(models, function(model){   get_climate_projections(     latitude = 37.30,     longitude = -79.83,     start_date = Sys.Date(),     end_date = Sys.Date() + lubridate::years(1),     model = model,     variables = c("temperature_2m_mean")) }) #> Waiting 5s for throttling delay ■■■■■■                           #> Waiting 5s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■                   #> Waiting 5s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■  #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■                           #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■                #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■  #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■                           #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■                 #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■  #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■                           #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■                 #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■   #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■  #> Waiting 5s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■                #> Waiting 5s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■  #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■                           #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■              #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■  #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■                           #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■              #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■ df |>    mutate(variable = paste(variable, unit)) |>    ggplot(aes(x = datetime, y = prediction, color = model_id)) +    geom_line() +   facet_wrap(~variable, scale = "free")

title: Example Usage
text: download multiple sites uses optional site_id add column denotes different sites.
code: sites <- tibble(site_id = c("fcre", "sunp"),                 latitude = c(37.30, 43.39),                 longitude = c(-79.83, -72.05))  df <- map_df(1:nrow(sites), function(i, sites){   get_climate_projections(     latitude = sites$latitude[i],     longitude = sites$longitude[i],     site_id = sites$site_id[i],     start_date = Sys.Date(),     end_date = Sys.Date() + lubridate::years(1),     model = "MPI_ESM1_2_XR",     variables = c("temperature_2m_mean")) }, sites) #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■                           #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■                 #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■  #> Waiting 5s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■               #> Waiting 5s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■  head(df) #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   datetime   site_id model_id      variable            prediction unit  #>   <date>     <chr>   <chr>         <chr>                    <dbl> <chr> #> 1 2024-08-27 fcre    MPI_ESM1_2_XR temperature_2m_mean       17.9 °C    #> 2 2024-08-28 fcre    MPI_ESM1_2_XR temperature_2m_mean       17.8 °C    #> 3 2024-08-29 fcre    MPI_ESM1_2_XR temperature_2m_mean       16.8 °C    #> 4 2024-08-30 fcre    MPI_ESM1_2_XR temperature_2m_mean       17.2 °C    #> 5 2024-08-31 fcre    MPI_ESM1_2_XR temperature_2m_mean       15.5 °C    #> 6 2024-09-01 fcre    MPI_ESM1_2_XR temperature_2m_mean       15   °C df |>    mutate(variable = paste(variable, unit)) |>    ggplot(aes(x = datetime, y = prediction, color = site_id)) +    geom_line() +   facet_wrap(~variable, scale = "free")

what: Converting from daily to hourly time-step
title: Example Usage
text: Photosynthesis non-linearly sensitive shortwave radiation. Therefore, photosynthesis response hourly radiation different response aggregated daily mean radiation. address issue, provide function convert daily sum shortwave radiation hourly values uses solar geometry impute. Additionally, sum precipitation divided 24 hours convert hourly time-step. variables daily mean applied hour.
code: df <- get_climate_projections(   latitude = 37.30,   longitude = -79.83,   start_date = Sys.Date(),   end_date = Sys.Date() + lubridate::years(1),   model = "EC_Earth3P_HR",   variables = glm_variables(product = "climate_projection", time_step = "daily")) #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■                           #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■               #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■  #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■                           #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■                #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■  #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■                           #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■                 #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■  #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■                           #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■                 #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■  #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■                  #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■   #> Waiting 6s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■  #> Waiting 5s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■                #> Waiting 5s for throttling delay ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■ df |>    daily_to_hourly(latitude = 37.30, longitude = -79.83) |>    mutate(variable = paste(variable, unit)) |>    ggplot(aes(x = datetime, y = prediction)) +    geom_line(color = "#F8766D") +    facet_wrap(~variable, scale = "free", ncol = 2)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Quinn Thomas. Author, maintainer, copyright holder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Thomas Q (2024). ropenmeteo: Wrappers 'Open-Meteo' API. R package version 0.1, http://flare-forecast.org/RopenMeteo/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {ropenmeteo: Wrappers for 'Open-Meteo' API},   author = {Quinn Thomas},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.1},   url = {http://flare-forecast.org/RopenMeteo/}, }

title: Wrappers for Open-Meteo API
text: R wrappers application programming interfaces Open-Meteo project. Open-Meteo amazing project streamlines access range publicly available historical forecast meteorology data agencies across world. free access tier allows 10,000 API calls per day. paid tiers increase number daily API calls . Learn Open-Meteo project website (https://open-meteo.com) consider supporting efforts. Open-Meteo citation: Zippenfenig, Patrick. (2023). Open-Meteo.com Weather API (0.2.69). Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.8112599 package includes additional functionally facilitate use mechanistic environmental/ecological models. includes calculation longwave radiation (provided API) air temperature cloud cover, writing output format required General Lake Model (GLM), conversion standard used NEON Ecological Forecasting Challenge run Ecological Initiative Research Coordination Network. package uses long format standard following columns datetime = date time forecasted value reference_datetime = date time beginning forecast (horizon = 0). apply historical weather. site_id = column identify site location. null function call defaults latitude_longitude model_id = id model generated forecast ensemble = ensemble member number (ensemble weather seasonal forecasts) variable = forecasted variable prediction = forecasted value unit = units variable

title: Wrappers for Open-Meteo API
text: Install development version GitHub :
code: devtools::install_github("FLARE-forecast/RopenMeteo")

title: Wrappers for Open-Meteo API
text: Ensemble forecasts individual models available. https://open-meteo.com/en/docs/ensemble-api resulting dataframe long format easily visualized using ggplot
code: library(RopenMeteo) library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) df <- RopenMeteo::get_ensemble_forecast(   latitude = 37.30,   longitude = -79.83,   forecast_days = 7,   past_days = 2,   model = "gfs_seamless",   variables = c("temperature_2m")) head(df) ## # A tibble: 6 × 8 ##   datetime            reference_datetime  site_id     model_id ensemble variable ##   <dttm>              <dttm>              <chr>       <chr>    <chr>    <chr>    ## 1 2024-08-20 00:00:00 2024-08-22 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 gfs_sea… 00       tempera… ## 2 2024-08-20 00:00:00 2024-08-22 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 gfs_sea… 01       tempera… ## 3 2024-08-20 00:00:00 2024-08-22 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 gfs_sea… 02       tempera… ## 4 2024-08-20 00:00:00 2024-08-22 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 gfs_sea… 03       tempera… ## 5 2024-08-20 00:00:00 2024-08-22 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 gfs_sea… 04       tempera… ## 6 2024-08-20 00:00:00 2024-08-22 00:00:00 37.3_-79.83 gfs_sea… 05       tempera… ## # ℹ 2 more variables: prediction <dbl>, unit <chr> df |>    mutate(variable = paste(variable, unit)) |>    ggplot(aes(x = datetime, y = prediction, color = ensemble)) +    geom_line() +    geom_vline(aes(xintercept = reference_datetime)) +    facet_wrap(~variable, scale = "free", ncol = 2)

title: Convert daily climate projections to hourly time-step — daily_to_hourly
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() get_climate_projections( latitude = 37.30, longitude = -79.83, start_date = Sys.Date(), end_date = Sys.Date() + lubridate::years(1), model = "EC_Earth3P_HR", variables = glm_variables(product = "climate_projection", time_step = "daily")) |> daily_to_hourly(latitude = 37.30, longitude = -79.83) }

what: Get set of variables required for the GLM model — glm_variables
title: Get set of variables required for the GLM model — glm_variables
text: Get set variables required GLM model

title: Get set of variables required for the GLM model — glm_variables
code: glm_variables(product, time_step)

title: Get set of variables required for the GLM model — glm_variables
text: product api type: climate, forecast, ensemble_forecast, historical, seasonal_forecast time_step model time-step: hourly, 6hour, daily

title: Get set of variables required for the GLM model — glm_variables
text: vector variables requires GLM model; vector can used variables argument API function calls (e.g., get_ensemble_forecast).

title: Get set of variables required for the GLM model — glm_variables
code: glm_variables(product = "ensemble_forecast", time_step = "hourly") #> [1] "relative_humidity_2m" "precipitation"        "wind_speed_10m"       #> [4] "cloud_cover"          "temperature_2m"       "shortwave_radiation"  #> [7] "surface_pressure"

title: Write ensemble forecast dataframe to General Lake Model formatted csv files — write_glm_format
code: file <- system.file("extdata", "test-data.csv", package="ropenmeteo") df <- readr::read_csv(file, show_col_types = FALSE) df |>    add_longwave() |>    write_glm_format(path = path)
